curam.util.client.domain.convert
Interface DomainConverter

All Superinterfaces:
DomainPlugIn, PlugIn
All Known Implementing Classes:
AbstractConverter, CodeTableCodeConverter, CuramTimeConverter, DateTimeConverter, DynamicTypeConverter, FrequencyPatternConverter, InternalIDConverter, LocalizedMessageConverter, SvrBlobConverter, SvrBooleanConverter, SvrCharConverter, SvrDateConverter, SvrDateTimeConverter, SvrDoubleConverter, SvrDoubleOneDecimalPlaceConvertor, SvrFloatConverter, SvrInt16BareConverter, SvrInt16Converter, SvrInt32BareConverter, SvrInt32Converter, SvrInt64BareConverter, SvrInt64Converter, SvrInt8BareConverter, SvrInt8Converter, SvrMoneyConverter, SvrStringConverter
public interface DomainConverter
extends DomainPlugIn

A domain plug-in class that converts data in the form supplied by the application server to and from a string representation used by the web tier. It can also validate data against domain-specific constraints and parse the generically formatted values used in the domain definition options for a domain in the UML model.

This interface must not be implemented directly. Instead, custom plug-in classes should extend an existing converter plug-in implementation or the curam.util.client.domain.convert.AbstractConverter class. All of the implementations of the methods on this interface have access to the locale, time zone, domain, and other context and plug-in configuration information via the inherited implementations of the methods on the super-interface that are available by extending the AbstractConverter class.

Constant Field Values
Method Detail

format

java.lang.String format(java.lang.Object data)
                        throws ConversionException

Formats the given object to a string representation. This may use the locale returned by PlugIn.getLocale() if required. This method is called before data returned from the application server is presented to the user. It can be used to convert data in the application representation to a human-readable form. The client infrastructure guarantees that this method will never be called with a null data value or with a data object that is incompatible with the class returned by the DomainConverter.getDomainClass() method, so neither check need be performed. However, it is recommended that a null value should trigger a NullPointerException.

The restriction on null values and values with an incompatible type are enforced by the implementation of the acceptData(Object) method inherited from the AbstractConverter base class. This method can be overridden to impose different or additional restrictions.

Parameters:
data - The data object to the formatted.
Returns:
The string representation of the data.
Throws:
ConversionException - If the formatting fails.

parse

java.lang.Object parse(java.lang.String data)
                       throws ConversionException
Parses the given string representation into an object. This may use the locale returned by PlugIn.getLocale() if required. This method is called after the relevant domain definition options specified in the application model have been applied (e.g., trimming and compressing whitespace, etc.), so the parsing routine does not have to perform those tasks. The client infrastructure guarantees that the data string will not be empty or null, so no checks need be performed for these conditions. However, it is recommended that a null should trigger a NullPointerException.

Parameters:
data - The string representation to be parsed.
Returns:
The data value using the appropriate type.
Throws:
ConversionException - If the parsing fails.

parseGeneric

java.lang.Object parseGeneric(java.lang.String data)
                              throws ConversionException
Parses the given generic string representation into an object of the appropriate type for the associated domain. This method is used to parse values expressed in the generic format used for some of the domain definition options in the UML model, e.g., default value, maximum value and minimum value. It is also used for values embedded in XML data passed to the client. Typically, this format is compatible with the user-entered format, so this method can be implemented to call the parse method or vice versa. However, for some types, e.g., dates, the formats are not compatible and a different implementation of the parser is required. The client infrastructure guarantees that the data string will not be empty or null, so no checks need be performed for these conditions. However, it is recommended that a null value should trigger a NullPointerException.

Parameters:
data - The generic string representation to be parsed.
Returns:
The data value using the appropriate type.
Throws:
ConversionException - If the parsing fails.

formatGeneric

java.lang.String formatGeneric(java.lang.Object data)
                               throws ConversionException

Formats the given object to a generic string representation. This method is used to format values such as those embedded in XML data. The formats used should be the same as those parsed by the DomainConverter.parseGeneric(String) method. Typically, this format is compatible with the user-entered format, so this method can be implemented to call the format method or vice versa. However, for some types, e.g., dates, the formats are not compatible and a different implementation of the formatter is required. The client infrastructure guarantees that this method will never be called with a null data value or with a data object that is incompatible with the class returned by the DomainConverter.getDomainClass() method, so neither check need be performed. However, it is recommended that a null value should trigger a NullPointerException.

The restriction on null values and values with an incompatible type are enforced by the implementation of the acceptData(Object) method inherited from the AbstractConverter base class. This method can be overridden to impose different or additional restrictions.

Parameters:
data - The data object to be formatted.
Returns:
The generic string representation of the data.
Throws:
ConversionException - If the formatting fails.

validate

void validate(java.lang.Object data)
              throws ConversionException
Validates an object according to the domain-specific constraints. Data is validated against the domain definition options specified in the application model before this method is called. This method can be used to perform extra validation that cannot be specified via the model. In most cases, a default implementation that does nothing will suffice. The client infrastructure guarantees that this method will never be called with a null data value or with a data object that is incompatible with the class returned by the DomainConverter.getDomainClass() method, so neither check need be performed. However, it is recommended that a null value should trigger a NullPointerException.

Parameters:
data - The data object to be validated.
Throws:
ConversionException - If the validation fails.

getDomainClass

java.lang.Class<?> getDomainClass()

Gets the class that is used for the native Java representation of data in this domain. The converter's format should be able to format instances of this class and the parse method should return instances of this class.

The client infrastructure will use this class to ensure that the converter methods are not passed an object of an incompatible type by checking this class in the implementation of the acceptData(Object) method inherited from the AbstractConverter base class.

Returns:
The native Java class used to represent this domain.

getGenericLocale

java.util.Locale getGenericLocale()
Gets the locale to be used when formatting or parsing generic values. This may or may not be the same as the user's active locale.

Returns:
The locale to used when formatting and parsing generic values.
